question:
What happens when two forces act in the opposite directions on an object?

SSC CGL Tier-1 2024
option_1: The net force acting on the object is the sum of the two forces
option_2: The net force acting on the object is the difference between the two forces
option_3: The object will move with acceleration zero
option_4: Forces will cancel out
solution:
• When two forces act in opposite directions on an object, the net force is the difference between the magnitudes of the two forces, acting in the direction of the larger force.
  • This is because forces in opposite directions subtract from each other to give the resultant force.
  • The object will accelerate in the direction of the net force unless the forces are equal, in which case the net force is zero.
  • Option (a) is incorrect because forces in opposite directions do not add, they subtract.
  • Option (c) is only true if the forces are equal, but not in general.
  • Option (d) is only true if forces are equal; otherwise, they do not completely cancel out.

Additional Information:

  • Net force determines the acceleration of an object according to Newton’s Second Law (F = ma).
  • Understanding the direction and magnitude of forces is crucial in mechanics.

question:
Identify the INCORRECT pair regarding motion and their examples?

SSC CGL Tier-1 2024
option_1: Oscillatory motion – Earth moving around the sun
option_2: Rotational motion – Earth spinning
option_3: Projectile motion – Javelin throw
option_4: Linear motion – Car moving
solution:
• The incorrect pair is (a) Oscillatory motion – Earth moving around the sun.
  • Earth moving around the sun is an example of revolution, which is a rotational or orbital motion, not oscillatory motion.
  • Oscillatory motion refers to back-and-forth repetitive motion about a mean position, such as a pendulum swinging.
  • The other pairs are correct:
    • Rotational motion: Earth spinning on its axis.
    • Projectile motion: Javelin throw follows a curved trajectory under gravity.
    • Linear motion: Car moving in a straight line.

Additional Information:

  • Oscillatory motion is periodic and involves vibration around a central point.
  • Revolution and rotation are different; revolution is motion around another body, rotation is spinning about its own axis.

question:
If a bar magnet is hung from a string, in which direction does its north pole point?

SSC CGL Tier-1 2024
solution:
• When a bar magnet is hung freely from a string, its north pole points towards the geographic North Pole of the Earth.
  • This happens because the Earth behaves like a giant magnet with its magnetic south pole near the geographic North Pole, attracting the north pole of the bar magnet.
  • Hence, the north pole of the magnet aligns itself along the Earth's magnetic field and points north.
  • The other directions (south, east, west) are incorrect in this context.

Additional Information:

  • This property of magnets is used in compasses to find directions.
  • The Earth's magnetic north is actually a magnetic south pole, which attracts the magnet’s north pole.
  • The alignment of magnets with Earth’s magnetic field is the basis of navigation.

question: What is the metric unit of pressure that is equal to 0.986923 atm?
solution:
• The unit that closely equals 0.986923 atm is the metric unit called "bar."
  • Correct Answer: (c) Bar
  • Key Point: 1 atm ≈ 1.01325 bar, so 0.986923 atm ≈ 1 bar.
  • Bar is not an SI unit but is widely used in science and engineering due to its convenience in expressing atmospheric-level pressures.
  • Units like yard, quart, and gallon are not pressure units—they measure length and volume respectively.

Additional Information:

  • 1 bar = 100,000 pascals (Pa)
  • Standard atmospheric pressure (1 atm) = 101,325 Pa

question: By observing the motion of objects on an inclined plane _______ deduced that objects move with a constant speed when no force acts on them.
solution:
• Galileo deduced that objects move with a constant speed on an inclined plane when no external force acts on them.
  • His experiments on inclined planes helped establish the concept of inertia and laid the foundation for Newton’s first law of motion.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is Galileo.

Additional Information:

  • Before Galileo, it was believed that a force was necessary to keep an object moving.
  • Galileo’s observations showed that an object in motion will continue to move unless acted upon by an external force.

question: The measure of the force that can cause an object to rotate about an axis is called:
solution:
• The measure of the force that can cause an object to rotate about an axis is called Torque.
  • Torque is the rotational equivalent of force and depends on the magnitude of the force and the perpendicular distance from the axis of rotation.
  • Hence, the correct answer is Torque.

Additional Information:

  • Power is the rate of doing work.
  • Moment of inertia is the resistance of an object to change in its rotational motion.
  • Centripetal force is the force that keeps an object moving in a circular path directed towards the center.

question: The forces exerted on a body during a short period are known as:
solution:
• The forces exerted on a body during a short period are known as Impulse.
  • Impulse is the product of force and the time interval during which the force acts.
  • It results in a change in the momentum of the object, expressed as:
  • Impulse = Force × Time = ΔMomentum
  • Impulse explains phenomena like how airbags reduce injury by increasing the time of impact, thus reducing force.
  • It is a vector quantity, having both magnitude and direction.

Additional Information:

  • Pressure is the force applied per unit area and is a scalar quantity.
  • Surface tension is responsible for phenomena like water droplets forming spheres and insects walking on water.
  • Tensile stress is the internal force per unit area within a material that resists stretching.

question: Which law was developed in the 1600s to describe that any force applied to a confined fluid is transmitted equally in all directions, regardless of the shape of the container?
solution:
• The law developed in the 1600s to describe that any force applied to a confined fluid is transmitted equally in all directions is Pascal’s Law.
  • It states that pressure applied to a confined fluid is transmitted undiminished throughout the fluid.
  • Hence, the correct answer is Pascal’s Law.

Additional Information:

  • Pascal’s Law is fundamental to hydraulics and explains how hydraulic presses and brakes work.
  • This principle helps in multiplying force in hydraulic systems.

question: The suitability of post tensioning is good for:
solution:
• The suitability of post-tensioning is best for long spans.
  • Post-tensioning allows for longer spans by applying tension to steel tendons after concrete has hardened, improving structural strength and reducing material usage.
  • Hence, the correct answer is Long spans.

Additional Information:

  • Post-tensioned structures are common in bridges, large buildings, and parking garages where long unsupported spans are required.
  • This method helps control cracking and deflection in concrete members.

question:
Select the option that is true regarding the following two statements labelled Assertion (A) and Reason (R).

(A): An object slips less on a rough surface than a smooth surface.

(R): When a surface is rough, frictional force increases.
option_1: Assertion (A) is true and Reason (R) is false
option_2: Both Assertion (A) and Reason (R) are the true but Reason (R) is not a correct explanation of Assertion (A)
option_3: Assertion (A) is false and Reason (R) is true
option_4: Both Assertion (A) and Reason (R) are the true and Reason (R) is a correct explanation of Assertion (A)
solution:
• Assertion (A): An object slips less on a rough surface than on a smooth surface. This is true because rough surfaces provide greater resistance to motion.
  • Reason (R): When a surface is rough, frictional force increases. This is also true as roughness increases the friction between surfaces.
  • Moreover, Reason (R) correctly explains Assertion (A) because increased friction on rough surfaces reduces slipping.
  • Hence, the correct answer is (d): Both Assertion (A) and Reason (R) are true and Reason (R) is a correct explanation of Assertion (A).

Additional Information:

  • Friction depends on the nature of surfaces and the normal force between them.
  • Higher friction reduces the tendency of slipping, providing better grip.

question: Newton’s first law of motion is also known as ________ .
solution:
• Newton’s first law of motion is also known as the Law of Inertia.
  • It states that an object at rest stays at rest, and an object in motion continues in motion at constant velocity unless acted upon by an external force.
  • Hence, the correct answer is Law of Inertia.
  • This law explains the resistance of objects to change their state of motion.

Additional Information:

  • The concept of inertia was first introduced by Galileo before Newton formalized it.
  • It is the fundamental principle underlying classical mechanics.
  • The law applies to both moving and stationary objects.

question: Which type of friction is considered as a self – adjusting force?
solution:
• Static friction is considered a self-adjusting force.
  • It adjusts its magnitude to match the applied force up to a maximum limit to prevent motion between two surfaces.
  • It acts when the object is at rest relative to the surface.
  • Once the applied force exceeds this maximum, the object starts to move and kinetic friction takes over.

Additional Information:

  • Kinetic friction has a constant value and does not adjust like static friction.
  • Rolling friction occurs when an object rolls over a surface and is usually less than static and kinetic friction.
  • Static friction plays a key role in preventing slipping and enabling walking or gripping.

question: The force exerted by a charged body on another charge or uncharged body is known as _______ .
solution:
• The force exerted by a charged body on another charged or uncharged body is known as Electrostatic force.
  • It arises due to the interaction between electric charges, attracting or repelling each other.
  • Electrostatic force follows Coulomb’s law and acts along the line joining the charges.
  • Hence, the correct answer is Electrostatic force.

Additional Information:

  • Electrostatic force is a non-contact force, meaning it acts without physical contact.
  • It is responsible for phenomena like static electricity, electric fields, and electric potential.
  • This force plays a key role in the behavior of atoms and molecules.

question: The substance which reduce friction are called _______ .
solution:
• The substances that reduce friction between two surfaces are called Lubricants.
  • Lubricants create a thin layer between surfaces, minimizing direct contact and thus reducing friction and wear.
  • Common lubricants include oil, grease, and graphite.
  • Hence, the correct answer is Lubricants.

Additional Information:

  • Lubricants help machines operate smoothly and increase their lifespan.
  • They also reduce heat generated due to friction.
  • Without lubricants, machines would wear out quickly due to excessive friction.

question: Which of the following statements is correct regarding air pressure?
option_1: High pressure is associated with cloudy skies and wet weather
option_2: Low pressure is associated with clear and sunny skies
option_3: The air always moves form high pressure areas to low pressure areas
option_4: The air pressure is lowest at sea level and increases with height
solution:
• The correct statement regarding air pressure is:
  • The air always moves from high pressure areas to low pressure areas.
  • This movement of air is due to pressure differences and is responsible for wind.
  • Hence, the correct answer is (c).

Additional Information:

  • High-pressure areas are generally associated with clear and sunny weather.
  • Low-pressure areas often bring cloudy skies and wet weather.
  • Air pressure decreases with increasing altitude, meaning it is highest at sea level.

question: A ball possesses 3000 units of momentum. What would be the ball’s new momentum if its velocity was doubled?
solution:
• Momentum (ppp) is given by the formula:
  • p = m × v
  • If the velocity (vvv) is doubled, the new momentum will be:
  • p_new = m × (2v) = 2 × (m × v) = 2p
  • Given the initial momentum is 3000 units, the new momentum will be:
  • 2 × 3000 = 6000 units
  • Hence, the correct answer is 6000 units.

Additional Information:

  • Momentum is directly proportional to velocity when mass is constant.
  • Doubling velocity doubles the momentum, while doubling mass would also double momentum.

question: Which of the following is NOT an application of the third law of motion?
option_1: A fielder pulls his hands gradually with the moving ball while holding a catch
option_2: Colliding with a player while kicking a football and feeling hurt
option_3: As the sailor jumps in the forward direction, the boat moves backward
option_4: A forward force on the bullet andrecoil of the gun
solution:
• The option (a) A fielder pulls his hands gradually with the moving ball while holding a catch is NOT an application of Newton’s third law of motion.
  • Newton’s third law states that for every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction.
  • Options (b), (c), and (d) clearly demonstrate action-reaction pairs, such as collision forces, boat recoil, and gun recoil.
  • In option (a), the fielder’s action is more about reducing impact by moving hands with the ball, not a direct equal and opposite force reaction scenario.

Additional Information:

  • Newton’s third law is evident in all interactions involving forces between two bodies.
  • It is fundamental to understanding phenomena like walking, swimming, and rocket propulsion.
  • Gradual pulling in catching reduces force, helping to hold the ball safely.

question: Which of the following is NOT a non-contact force?
solution:
• The force which is NOT a non-contact force among the options is Friction.
  • Friction is a contact force that arises when two surfaces are in physical contact and oppose motion.
  • Gravitational, Electrostatic, and Magnetic forces act without physical contact, so they are non-contact forces.
  • Hence, the correct answer is Friction.

Additional Information:

  • Non-contact forces act at a distance, without the need for physical touching.
  • Friction depends on the nature of surfaces and the normal force pressing them together.
  • Gravitational force acts between any two masses regardless of distance.

question: Which of the following is the correct order of friction?
solution:
• The correct order of frictional forces is:
  • Static friction > Sliding friction > Rolling friction
  • Static friction is the maximum force that must be overcome to start moving an object.
  • Sliding friction occurs when two surfaces slide over each other and is less than static friction.
  • Rolling friction is the smallest among the three and occurs when an object rolls over a surface.
  • Hence, the correct answer is (c) Static > Sliding > Rolling.

Additional Information:

  • Static friction prevents the start of motion.
  • Sliding friction opposes motion once it has started.
  • Rolling friction is why wheels reduce the effort needed to move objects.

question: Identify the correct statement about inertia.
option_1: Greater the mass, greater the inertia
option_2: Lesser the weight, greater the inertia
option_3: Lesser the mass, greater the inertia
option_4: Greater the mass, lesser inertia
solution:
• The correct statement about inertia is:
  • Greater the mass, greater the inertia.
  • Inertia is the property of a body to resist changes in its state of motion.
  • The more massive an object is, the more it resists changes in its motion.
  • Hence, the correct answer is (a).

Additional Information:

  • Weight is the force due to gravity and depends on location, but inertia depends only on mass.
  • Inertia is why heavier objects are harder to start or stop moving.
  • Inertia applies to both objects at rest and in motion.

question: The motion of _______ body is an example of uniformly accelerated motion.
solution:
• The motion of a freely falling body is an example of uniformly accelerated motion.
  • In free fall, the body accelerates downward due to gravity at a constant rate (approximately 9.8 m/s2) ignoring air resistance.
  • Hence, the correct answer is (d) Freely falling.

Additional Information:

  • A resting body has zero velocity and zero acceleration.
  • Decelerating motion implies negative acceleration, not necessarily uniform acceleration.
  • Parabolic motion involves acceleration due to gravity but includes horizontal velocity, so it’s not uniformly accelerated in all directions.

question: Motion of an object is ______ if its velocity is constant.
solution:
• The motion of an object is called uniform if its velocity is constant.
  • Uniform motion means the object covers equal distances in equal intervals of time without changing speed or direction.
  • Hence, the correct answer is (d) uniform.

Additional Information:

  • If velocity changes, the motion is non-uniform.
  • Accelerating means velocity is increasing, while decelerating means velocity is decreasing.
  • Uniform motion can be in a straight line or along a curved path if speed remains constant.

question: ______ time graph shows speed of an object.
solution:
• A distance-time graph shows the speed of an object.
  • The slope of a distance-time graph gives the speed since speed = distance/time.
  • Hence, the correct answer is (b) Distance.

Additional Information:

  • A velocity-time graph shows velocity and can indicate acceleration.
  • Displacement-time graph shows displacement which includes direction.
  • Acceleration-time graph shows how acceleration changes with time.

question: Which physical theory explains the generation of thrust by rocket engines, jet engines and deflating balloons?
option_1: Newton’s laws of motion
option_3: Faradays’s laws of electromagnetic induction
solution:
• The generation of thrust by rockets, jets, and balloons is explained by Newton’s third law of motion.
  • For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction.
  • When gases are expelled backward, they push the vehicle forward.
  • This principle applies to rockets, jets, and deflating balloons.
  • Hence, the correct answer is Newton’s laws of motion.

Additional Information:

  • Newton’s third law is fundamental in propulsion systems.
  • It helps explain motion in space and atmosphere.
  • Rockets use combustion gases to produce thrust.
  • Balloons move forward by releasing air backward.

question: Which of the following intermolecular is also called the London force?
solution:
• The intermolecular force also called the London force is Dispersion Forces.
  • These are weak forces arising due to temporary fluctuations in electron distribution in atoms and molecules.
  • Dispersion forces are present in all molecules but are the only forces in nonpolar molecules.
  • Hence, the correct answer is (a) Dispersion Forces.

Additional Information:

  • London forces increase with the size and mass of molecules.
  • They contribute to boiling and melting points of nonpolar substances.
  • Other intermolecular forces include dipole-dipole, dipole-induced dipole, and hydrogen bonding, which are generally stronger.

question:
Which of the following statements is correct?

I. Rolling friction is greater than the sliding friction.

II. The frictional force exerted by fluids is called drag.
option_2: Neither I nor II is correct
option_3: Both I and II are correct
option_4: Only II is correct
solution:
• Statement I: Rolling friction is greater than sliding friction — This is false; rolling friction is usually much less than sliding friction.
  • Statement II: The frictional force exerted by fluids is called drag — This is true.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is (d) Only II is correct.

Additional Information:

  • Rolling friction helps reduce effort in moving objects with wheels.
  • Drag force opposes the motion of objects moving through fluids (liquids or gases).
  • Sliding friction requires more force to overcome compared to rolling friction.

question: Which law of Newton provides a quantitative definition of force?
option_1: Universal law of gravitation
option_2: Second law of motion
option_3: First law of motion
option_4: Third law of motion
solution:

question: The range of ________ force is of the order of 10-16 m.
solution:
• Weak nuclear force is responsible for processes like beta decay in radioactive atoms.
  • This force acts only over very short distances, typically around 10⁻¹⁶ meters.
  • Electromagnetic and gravitational forces have infinite range, though their strength weakens with distance.
  • The strong nuclear force, while also short-ranged, operates at a slightly larger range (~10⁻¹⁵ m) than the weak force.

Hence, the force with a range of ~10⁻¹⁶ m is the weak nuclear force.

Additional Information:

  • The weak nuclear force is one of the four fundamental forces in nature (gravitational, electromagnetic, strong nuclear, and weak nuclear).
  • It is mediated by W and Z bosons.
  • It is weaker than the strong and electromagnetic forces, but stronger than gravity at subatomic levels.

question: If two forces act on an object from opposite directions. Then the magnitude of the net force acting on it is the _______ of the magnitudes of the two forces.
solution:
Correct Option: (d) Difference

  • Key Concept:
  • Net force = |F₁ - F₂| (when forces oppose each other)
  • Step-by-Step:
    1. Let F₁ and F₂ be two forces in opposite directions.
    2. Net force magnitude = Absolute difference (|F₁ - F₂|).
  • Why not others?
  • • Sum (b) → Only for same direction.
  • • Product/Ratio → Never used for net force.

Additional Information:

  1. Real-world Example:
    • Tug-of-war: If Team A pulls with 500N left and Team B with 300N right, net force = 200N left.
  2. Special Cases:
    • Equal forces (F₁=F₂) → Net force = 0 (balanced forces).
  3. Units:
    • Force: Newton (N) = kg·m/s².

question: Which of the following is a characteristic of conservative force?
option_1: Energy is dissipated as heat energy
option_2: Work done by it in a round trip is not zero
option_3: Work done by it depends upon the path
option_4: Work done by it is completely recoverable
solution:
• A conservative force is a force where the work done does not depend on the path taken but only on the initial and final positions.
  • The work done by a conservative force in a closed loop (round trip) is always zero.
  • Since conservative forces store energy within the system and do not dissipate it as heat, the correct answer is (d) Work done by it is completely conservative.

Additional Information:

  • Examples of conservative forces include:
    • Gravitational force
    • Electrostatic force
    • Spring force
  • The work done by non-conservative forces (like friction) depends on the path and often leads to energy dissipation as heat.
  • The conservation of mechanical energy applies when only conservative forces act on a system.

question: Which of the following is NOT a scalar quantity?
solution:
• Scalar quantities are those that have magnitude only and no direction.
  • Vector quantities have both magnitude and direction.
  • Torque is a vector quantity because it has a magnitude and a specific rotational direction (clockwise or counterclockwise).
  • The correct answer is (c) Torque.

Additional Information:

  • Examples of scalar quantities:
    • Volume (Only has magnitude, no direction)
    • Temperature (Represents heat intensity but no direction)
    • Time (Has magnitude but no directional component)
  • Examples of vector quantities:
    • Force (Has both magnitude and direction)
    • Velocity (Indicates speed and direction of motion)
    • Acceleration (Shows rate of change of velocity with direction)
  • Torque is given by the formula:

Torque=Force × PerpendicularDistance

  • Unit of torque:Newton-meter (N·m)
  • Direction is determined using the right-hand rule.

question: The force that opposes the relative motion between two surfaces in contact is called
solution:
• The force that opposes the relative motion between two surfaces in contact is called frictional force.
  • Friction acts parallel to the surfaces and opposite to the direction of motion or attempted motion.
  • It arises due to the microscopic irregularities on the surfaces in contact.
  • Friction plays a crucial role in everyday life, enabling walking, driving, and gripping objects.
  • There are different types of friction: static friction, kinetic friction, and rolling friction.

Additional Information:

  • Friction converts kinetic energy into heat, causing wear and tear of materials.
  • Excessive friction can lead to energy loss, which is why lubricants are used to reduce friction.
